We’ll see examples showing this is NOT sufficient. 1.1 Some Basic defnitions Definition 1.1 (Homotopy of Maps) Let \(X, Y\) be topological spaces, and let \(f, g : X 	o Y\) be continuous maps. We say that \(f\) is homotopic to \(g\), and write \(f \sim g\), if there exists a continuous map \[ H : X 	imes I 	o Y \] such that \[ H(x,0) = f(x), \qquad H(x,1) = g(x) \quad 	ext{for all } x \in X. \] Intuitively, the map \(H\) defines a continuous deformation of \(f\) into \(g\) over time \(t \in [0,1]\). Notations: We often write \(H_t : X 	o Y\) for the slice \(H(\cdot,t)\), so that \(H_0 = f, \quad H_1 = g.\) Sometimes we write \(f \overset{H}{\sim} g\) to indicate the specific homotopy \(H\). Example 1.2 Let \(f, g : X 	o \mathbb{R}^n\) be any continuous functions. Then \(f \sim g\), because we can define a homotopy: \[ H(x,t) = t\, g(x) + (1 - t)\, f(x) \] This map \(H : X 	imes I 	o \mathbb{R}^n\) is continuous (since vector space operations in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) are continuous), and satisfies: \[ H_0 = f, \qquad H_1 = g \] Definition 1.2 Let \(A \subset X\), and suppose \(f|_A = g|_A\), i.e., \(f(a) = g(a)\) for all \(a \in A\). We say that \(f\) is homotopic to \(g\) relative to \(A\) if there exists a homotopy \[ H : X 	imes I 	o Y \] such that \[ H(a,t) = f(a) = g(a) \quad 	ext{for all } a \in A, 	ext{ and all } t \in [0,1]. \] Example 1.3 Let \(f, g : I 	o \mathbb{R}^2\) be continuous maps (paths), as illustrated. Hence, \(H\) is a homotopy relative to the endpoints \(\{0,1\} \subset I\).
